media.description: We received these nice glasses at work, the only problem is that they are all alike and it is nearly impossible to know which glass belongs to whom.
media.title: photo 1.JPG

media.description: Copied the appropriate font, adjusted kerning and scale in Silhouette cutter software.
media.title: photo 3.JPG

media.description:
I used my friends vinyl cutter to cut a template to adhere to the glass.
Not picutred, I taped a piece of paper over the side with existing printing and traced the shape of the angled "here" text, then taped the template to the other side of the glass and copied the tracing to the inside of the  glass with dry erase marker to have registration markings to be used to place the vinyl mask.
media.title: photo 2.JPG

media.description: With the extra vinyl I decided to etch a beer bottle with the dream of having a monogrammed beer collection.  This however was doomed to fail...
media.title: photo 5.JPG

media.description: Finished glass back, I will never loose my glass again.
media.title: photo 2-01.JPG

media.description: Unfortunately it did not turn out perfectly.  I was rushing and this was the first etching I ever did.  I did not thoroughly clean and dry the glass first, I did not use fresh vinyl, but rather the outer shell of an old roll that had seen some wear and whose adhesive may have blistered and lost some stick, and I did not properly, thoroughly burnish the mask.  Some combination of these factors led to the etchant getting under the mask in the upper corner of the last "t".  Lesson learned.
media.title: photo 3-01.JPG

media.description:
The bottle etching was doomed from the start.
The bottle was cold and constantly sweat preventing the adhesive from sticking, and I picked the absolutely most rounded part of the bottle possible, it would have been a serious challenge to get anything to stick there under ideal circumstances.  But, it is legible and it was fun  :-)
media.title: photo 4-01.JPG
